sentence: an app experiment how much do i really need dedicated apps with a desktopclass version of safari can i add the bookmark icon to my toolbar in safari anyone having wifi connection issues with ipad mini 7? downgraded m4 back to ipad pro m1 much better for the eyes!
looks like m4 ipad pro is a bit of a flop on a relative basis apple earnings pilot choice for ipad using foreflight wifi cellular ?
pretty, i wish it were a macbook the ipad pro with m4 and oled is significantly more powerful and colorful than the previous generation.
this is one of the reasons i dislike bst.

new ipad pros that may have slightly bigger screens but with large spec bumps too updated ipad air including the introduction of a 12.9 ipad air new apple pencil 3 with various rumours surrounding find my and changeable tips new magic keyboard to make the whole thing look more like a macbook no mention of ipad mini and the one take away from the various videos i've watched is that there is a very real concern that the new ipad pros will have a large price like with the 13 inch coming in around or over 1500 and that may be why there will be a larger air to pacify people somewhat.
it'd be typical if they redesigned the magic keyboard for macs too as i've just been out and bought one i would love to see a new ipad mini...i know, talk is not this time!
airpods max refresh would be good. how likely it is though.
but not till 2025 so very unlikely for this event.
would like to be wrong as i fancy a pair although ideally with all the features the airpods pro 2 have.
oh wow looks like my wallet will be a big hit the wife wants a new ipad pro after her old one broke.
and i hope you're having a great day!
i love my 10.5inch ipad pro, but if i were buying right now, i'd go with one of the newer 11inch models, primarily for the usbc connectivity.
it does reduce pencil lag but even 60 hz ain't all that bad there.
agree with others mostly, if you can get a new battery and still be well under the price of an 11 pro, it's still a great ipad.
poor battery life after 4 years usbcthunderbolt larger screen went 12.9 were my motivating factors to upgrade, but aside from the battery my 10.5 still feels capable.
i just sold a 2nd gen and it was still a very capable machine and i was actively using it for professional illustration work.
i've heard its like 400600 when i investigated it for 3rd party prices were around 150175 but i have heard that through apple it's much higher.
im still using one as a daily driver and it holds up well.
theres a large thread about screen issues with the second gen pro, which is why id recommend a newer model after saving a bit more.
a10x is still capable and even has more ram than a11, still love and use my gen 2 12.9 daily.
plenty fast and a great screen. its still a great ipad.
its just such a great machine, i already have the case, keyboard and pencil for it, it works really well and really fast, and for now i have zero interest in anything newer.
given the inherently limited nature of ipados, i dont believe theres anything that a newer ipad can do that the 2017 version doesnt do excellently as well.
in fact, browsing web on ipad pro is better than my 2015 mpb.
the design of the new ipad pro is probably the best overall feature, and the drop in weight and thickness makes a difference whether you're traveling or just using the ipad around the house.
at 5.1mm, the 13inch ipad pro is apple's thinnest device to date, and a tablet of this size and thickness continues to be impressive.
it's much more natural than treating the ipad like a giant iphone.
it is by far the best display that apple has introduced in an ipad, and you won't find a better tablet display available from competing products, either.
movies look amazing, the ipad does well in bright lighting, and the hdr makes images pop.
compared to the priorgeneration ipad pro with miniled display, the oled display is better, but not so much so that it's worth upgrading for that alone.
apple nixed both the ultra wide camera and mmwave 5g in this version of the ipad pro, and most people probably won't miss these features.

so you don't need to go hunting for settings to do things like change line thickness or color, and there's a barrel roll feature that basically does things like vary line thickness when tilting the apple pencil so it behaves more like a real writing or drawing tool.
the magic keyboard is way more mac like to that larger glass trackpad and the aluminum palm rest.

the trackpad is more pleasant to use than before, and the function keys are also a big plus for controlling media, changing screen brightness, and more without having to dig into the settings app or control center.
unsurprisingly, the ipad pro is without a doubt apple's best ipad, and it's probably the best tablet on the market.
those are mac prices, and while the ipad's hardware is worth it, it's a lot to pay for the limitations that you're stuck with when using ipados.

i'm not going to because there is no reason beyond the svelte aesthetics, i barley make use of the capabilities of the m2 ipad pro, and i'd just put a case on it anyway... without the ability to run many macos app, i cant convince myself to pay for an ipad pro that is more expensive than macbook airpro those are mac prices, and while the ipad's hardware is worth it, it's a lot to pay for the limitations that you're stuck with when using ipados.
of course apple would charge 800 for a headless laptop thats slower than a macbook air but they wouldn't have it any other way.

i mean, the new keyboard is great if you want to use it as a macbook, but to me the smart folio keyboard represented the perfect half way solution for those that use and carry the ipad mainly as a tablet, but still want to use a physical keyboard when required.
i bought it have compared it to my 2018 ipad pro and it's barely any lighter or thinner.
i upgraded from an m1 12.9 ipp and got exactly what i was hoping for an allday battery ipad pro, in a lighter formfactor with a matte screen.

where i used to just barely get through an 8 hour day using it on and off unplugged, i can get a full day of use, plus a night of entertainment use on it and still have 30 battery remaining to start the next day.
its one of the best apple products ive ever owned and ive owned a lot of them going back to the early 90s.
to that document, i just learned that the new m4 ipad pro not only has one ambient light sensor like my m2 ipp but three!!!
one annoying issue i have with my m2 ipad pro, is that if i block the ambient light sensor where faceid is, the screen gets a lot dimmer.
i could definitely notice a major improvement to those dramatic physical reductions.
apple would like to sell a lot of these very expensive ipads pro. yesterday i went to an apple store and made a sidebyside comparison of new ipad pro 13 vs new ipad air 13.
to me, both displays are amazing and my eyes aren't good enough to perceive the added value of oled.
the serious work crowd are just using that line to justify their overpriced purchase.
if you mix live audio, this ipad would be fantastic.

without reading it let me guess, the higher res screen is nicer, the spec bump is faster, the speakers are slightly upgraded, but the software still sucks and is exactly the same as the 2018 ipad pro. great for people who draw? , and you'll see fewer ads.
yes, looks like theres quite a few reports of this wonder if it's the stacked oled displays?
apart from my small sleep wake delay when tapping or pressing the button, the ipad m4 is great.
its most noticeable at mid brightnesses on graymuted colours and looks like a photo taken with high isolots of film grain but very fine.
i compared it like for like to my m2 ipad pro and its not there on that one, even taking account of the tint differences of the two screens.
haha no normal distances, with my eyes i cant focus on anything easily much closer than normal distance so definitely not in my face i have the nano display and even its not the slightest bit grainy.
love the upgrade for the screen alone.
the ipad pro 10.5 is a great ipad you can buy if you want an apple tablet that balances entertainment, productivity and a sleek 10.5inch form factor.
to know everything that's coming, visit our the 10.5inch ipad pro in 2017 represents apple deciding to make a tablet with absolutely everything crammed in.
the best in audio performance, the cream of the company's mobile screen tech, and all the power that can be crammed inside the metal walls of a digital slate.

like the larger onboard, its new software make it more versatile than when it first launched, although you can now upgrade it to there's only so much manufacturers can do to update a tablet these days beyond increasing the specs, as the use case for these devices hasn't altered much over the years, beyond them now being able to serve as pseudotablet replacements with the addition of a keyboard.

we expect it to drop once we hear all about the new anyone looking to give up some prolevel features for a cheaper tablet can find it in the if you're familiar with any ipad, then the new ipad pro isn't going to be a surprise.
even with the smart keyboard attached it's almost impossible to detect the presence of the new ipad pro when it's thrown in a bag, and on its own it's a great tablet to hold for extended periods.
it feels redundant to talk about the build quality of this tablet, because the higher premium placed on apple products does guarantee something that's made to last and feel good in the hand.
the screen on the 10.5inch ipad pro is one of the best we've seen on a tablet, to the wider color gamut, brightness and overall sharpness.
but there's a feeling that it's overkill, especially as it's likely the reason the cost has risen so much.
it's definitely an upgrade, although you feel like it's still constrained somehow, as the 12.9inch model is just so much more expansive.

however, there is more screen real estate to play with, while apple has maintained sharpness levels by putting 1668 x 2224 pixels onto the display to balance out by the larger size, which is a good move.
that's a great thing in theory, as the visual quality of some programming on the ipad will look amazing.
the promotion display technology is something that's worth looking at in greater depth, as it's something apple highlighted many times during the launch and during demonstrations.

however, we kept feeling that just flicking around the new 10.5inch ipad pro was just a generally more slick experience there's definitely an upgrade both visually and in terms of speed under the finger.

the truetone display is a hard one to assess it mimics the lighting conditions around you by measuring the color of what's doing the illuminating, so the screen will look different when using it by lamplight and outdoors.
then you'll see there's a genuine and pleasant difference, especially when using the new ipad pro by lamplight.
if you're an apple fan and just crave the best of what's on offer, then this tablet will impress without a doubt.
i would mainly use it for stuff like goodnotes, word with magic keyboard, some garageband although i prefer that on a lap or desktop, and the odd and fairly simple procreate project.
i was using an air2 up until 2 weeks ago and although slow at times it still worked fine for normal everyday use.
i brought a refurnished 2015 ipad 12.9 at woot.com four months ago at low price and man, the estate of the screen really blew my mind after using ipad 9.7 and 10.2 for several years.
it's worth it.
so i imagine it would be a good fit for your use case.
the magic keyboard is a great accessory and is compatible with the latest m2 based ipad pro as well, giving you a decent upgrade path.
i noticed apples refurbished store had several discounted 12.9 ipad pro 2018 or newer so you a want to double check that the deal youre getting is as good as what you can pick up from apple.
as for refurbished, that's absolutely what i would go for but unfortunately, it's not available directly from apple here it is extraordinarily useful in 2022.
for your use case it's actually better that the m1, because it's lighter.
i barely notice the speed difference with m1 in normal use sure you can see it side by side, but it's a bit like going from 1440p to 2160p 4k on a laptop screen.
they are both very sharp just like m1 and a12x are still both very smooth other than in some extreme scenarios.
it doesnt mean that its ideal, but i doubt itll be absolutely horrible.
i was only worried about the ram, but in the store it was super fast snd fluid even editing photos with no difference in performance at all compared to the pro that was next to it.
all other tasks will heat up mu air 2 with good lag and extremely slow loading times.
on the other hand, the 2018 ipad pro is still a very good tablet.
so it actually does pretty good as far as performance goes.
i didn't think updating to ios15 was necessary as i really prefer the layout and interface of ios14 when compared to the changes made to the ipad on ios15.

the air 2 felt slow already on ios 12 when you also had the 9.7 pro... i call this the spoil effect, a faster device spoils you and you find you older one too slow... 15 years ago nobody complained about hdds, now with ssds, hdds feel unbearably slow.
the m1 had definitely not managed to spoil me in the slightest, the only real advantage is ram, in terms of speed the experience is very similar.
most typical example when it's annoying is youtube i don't use the youtube app, because safari allows me to watch youtube adfree for free.
an ipad for the most part cannot run backgrond apps like desktops, and i don't use split screen because it's cramped, let alone stage manager, which is pretty bad at this stage.
but other than that the 2018 is virtually just as smooth and is actually lighter, so more pleasant to hold.
great screen, great speakers, fast, light, apple pencil pro is a game changer.
i dont think anyone will argue ipads have bestinclass hardware, but everyone would benefit from software improvements.
a tablet lends itself to fullscreen applications and focus work, like writing in a book or drawing on paper.
more options for tiling windows when not using stage manager would be nice.
those are probably the most difficult things to improve, but would net the biggest benefit to users if they can be.
as cockney rebel said though, the m4 ipp is a fantastic device absolutely love it.
i'd take a mini 6 size too, but i absolutely agree with your take here.
pretty disappointed it wasnt added to the m4s.
with software i want native mac app support on ipados and i want them to make external display support feel like its not a beta feature.
this is an annoying, useless artifact.
it weighs like a brick without the magic keyboard so you can't put it in the palm of your hand and hold it onehanded and scribble with the pencil with the other hand.
it's terrible fr watching content because the aspect ratio is not optimised for watching filmstv.
safari on the ipad is terrible compared to chrome on desktop.
you might think annotating with the pencil would be great on this big screen but think again.
for annotating and taking notes, which is 1 of 2 things this device is mainly good at, you can get away with buying a much cheaper ipad.
i'd like to know how people who use and like this device get around these huge shortcomings of such an expensive device.
but it certainly isnt light, especially with the mk i find the mk is fine on my lap i was surprised actually text input without a keyboard, i agree.

i agree, but i wouldnt want to change the aspect ratio as then it would be bad for normal use i annotate all the time, i really think it works well i use a matt screen protector though, else its horrible to write on.

what's funny is the 12.9 screen is actually a perfect size in landscape mode for a properlysized keyboard, and if i make sure my hands are centered before typing, i can touchtype blindly on the screen just from the key spacing being just right if you're using the pencil, there is a button at the bottom that shows a onehanded keyboard.
i have never missed having a laptop or mac whilst using this device but thats because of how i personally use it.
i like that it has 5g connectivity, especially for train trips.
for viewing content, the ipad has always been worse than an android tablet, but for productivity, the screen on the ipad is much better, since you see more content.
in my experience it has a serious personality disorder and identity crisis.
a little too unwieldy to fully enjoy as a sofa tablet.
thus works best as a pseudo laptop with magic keyboard, but then i soon realised it was half a laptop with a crippled operating system and almost no io.
i have a 21x9 monitor and i love watching films in native resolution

i agree safari is not as good as a desktop version and that is probably one of my biggest gripes about the ipad as for on screen keyboard when using input fields i just tested this with the chatgpt app and it pops up every time i select the field with pen in hand
i take it everywhere to keep all that access whilst still having the ability to use generally excellent iosipados apps to run my photography business.
its better than a laptop for many things its a lot nicer and much more professional to hand my clients a sample gallery with an ipad than to shove a macbook in their face.
in the situations where its not good enough to do a task, i use either a selfhosted docker application via a browser or i remote in to my other machines.
how depressing it is to find out my most used and most loved apple product, my 12.9 m2 pro, is so disappointing!
it becomes quite easy to hold in my opinion.
overpriced for that stuff?
why post x is no good for me and then assume that makes it no good for ?
sounds like someone was duped into thinking that ipad was a replacement for a mac.
safari on ipad isnt like chrome on desktop and this salad doesnt taste as good as this soup.
my 12.9 ipad pro is probably my most used device after my iphone and my work desktop.
im not gonna deny it should probably be a bit cheaper for the hardware in it but for the use ive had out of mine is given me excellent value.
the design of the new ipad pro is probably the best overall feature, and the drop in weight and thickness makes a difference whether you're traveling or just using the ipad around the house.
at 5.1mm, the 13inch ipad pro is apple's thinnest device to date, and a tablet of this size and thickness continues to be impressive.
it's much more natural than treating the ipad like a giant iphone.
it is by far the best display that apple has introduced in an ipad, and you won't find a better tablet display available from competing products, either.
movies look amazing, the ipad does well in bright lighting, and the hdr makes images pop.
compared to the priorgeneration ipad pro with miniled display, the oled display is better, but not so much so that it's worth upgrading for that alone.
apple nixed both the ultra wide camera and mmwave 5g in this version of the ipad pro, and most people probably won't miss these features.

so you don't need to go hunting for settings to do things like change line thickness or color, and there's a barrel roll feature that basically does things like vary line thickness when tilting the apple pencil so it behaves more like a real writing or drawing tool.
the magic keyboard is way more mac like to that larger glass trackpad and the aluminum palm rest.

the trackpad is more pleasant to use than before, and the function keys are also a big plus for controlling media, changing screen brightness, and more without having to dig into the settings app or control center.
unsurprisingly, the ipad pro is without a doubt apple's best ipad, and it's probably the best tablet on the market.
those are mac prices, and while the ipad's hardware is worth it, it's a lot to pay for the limitations that you're stuck with when using ipados.
but i really don't think it's fullblown macos that people are wanting on their ipad so much as it is wanting more maclike app experiences and openness of the operating system.

or if it is true macos that people are itching for, it seems to me that in their minds it wouldn't completely supplant ipados but rather only be available as an option when the ipad detects that appropriate accessories are connected like an external display, mouse andor keyboard, which probably would be the optimal approach for getting the best of both worlds.
even if im a heavy mac user, im used to the phone paradigm, where interaction is much more direct, and i find it much easier and enjoyable for everyday and creative tasks.
using an ipad is much more natural than a traditional pc to me.

there are many compromises made to end up with a bad experience, awkwardly switching between os that look completely different on the same device, which is not designed for macos in terms of battery, size, thermals, trackpad size, etc. its an idea that sounds good in theory but wouldnt work in practice.
the display is excellent and they're good for a lot of things, i just can't get past that eye watering price.
it's just the interface that's different, and i certainly don't want them messing with the mac interface for the sake of the ipad.
we have great examples of how people really use the windows tablets.
so a giant phone will be better than a traditional computer, regardless of the price.
handwriting response is good enough that i might actually be able to use it to take notes in real time, ideally in cursive haven't been able to do that with any prior ipads.

but i really do think that for a device with tech this advanced and a price this stratospheric, apple really does need to provide us with real windows management and a really intuitive file systemnot stage manager and the files app, both of which feel like cobbledtogether messes.
both arent great if their goal is to sell both.
if they add a macos like mode that prevents a macbook air sale they got macbook pro revenue anyway they cant let the surface products continue to offer a contrast.
the root error of the analysis is thinking that ipados is objectively worse than macos, and apple is selling a worse product at a higher price.
windows wasnt a good tablet or mobile os.
i do feel this is enough of an upgrade that after 4 great years, i'm ready to upgrade my old 2020 ipad pro 12.9 to this new 13 version.

sure, the one i have now still works flawlessly and does what i need it to do and i'll never even tap into a quarter of the power that one has but this new one does look great and now that it's even thinner and lighter and probably have even better speakers and all the other stuff, it's worth the steep price.
it's the best ipad i've ever owned pound for pound
i have the regular smart folio and i prefer to remove it from the case anytime im using the ipad on the couch or in bed.
i bought it have compared it to my 2018 ipad pro and it's barely any lighter or thinner.
my m1 is amazing for all my needs!

the fact that they just launched final cut for ipad pro means that macos apps will not be available for ipad this year, no matter how much we wished but for the price difference, you can literally buy 10 or more pencils everywhere around your house and it is still cheaper and then someone tries to run an llm with ollama or someone else loads a monster scene into blender and then their ipad turns to toast, the screen damages from the heat, the device becomes too hot to hold.
the new pros are fantastic ipads.
with the magic keyboard i cant use the pencil pro very good to write or draw, i would have to use it blank and am scared it gets scratched on raw surfaces.

now im thinking about using the magic keyboard and keeping the folio case with me, in case i want to writedraw for longer, or if i should just use the magic keyboard at home or whatever else i could do.
this is great because dirt and debris trapped inside will scratch the ipad causing a unique look.
it's amazing that otterbox being the only thirdparty company to sell on apple.com on day 1, doesn't take advantage of this in any way.
other than the smart cover hinge on the bottom, it looks like a cheapo amazon case id buy until the good ones come to market.
id permanently glue that pencil drawer shut, probably cut that flap off or glue it down if it doesnt hold, and bingo a cheapo case!
hopefully it will be better or at least good enough to tide me over until something better gets released.
no way id just throw this in a bag like this.
using it on my lap as we speak and it stays much better than my twogensprior apple folio.
anyone afraid that the edges of the ipad will not be protected if using the ipad folio?
adding a dbrand skin to the folio may be best of both worlds provided it offers side, top, and bottom stickers.
this new ipad is so light and thin.. schleping it everywhere necessitates the need for good protection.
not so good. apple used to make good ipad cases.
i wanted something other than black so am looking at the zugu case which comes in various colors and has good reviews.
i actually like the statement case because i want the kickstand, but my volume buttons are basically impossible to press and its a hard deal breaker, especially on a 90 case.
i just want a case with a surface like kickstand and purchased both this and the logitech combo touch and dont love either.
all these other bulky cases and folios such are definitely not the answer.
i am also in search for a case with a similar kickstand, for now the esr shift case works for me. feels and looks great.
it seems very well made and looks like it will give great protection, but i definitely notice the weight.
also, the case itself scuffs like crazy.
it's best to keep that in mind when considering this case.
i like the little drawer for the pencil.
its not fabric but somehow feels like softer texture than the rest of the case.
thats definitely something to complain about for some of you.
no wobbles! tested the case in bed and unsurprisingly it worked perfectly.
raising the ipad those few inches gives a better viewing angle on a desk, counter etc.. the best part is it's still sturdy to the point that i'm comfortable using it this way in bed.
but it would be great if these edges were rounded off.
additionally this is hands down better than my old zugu case which surprised me.
for watching, don't forget to like, sub...
i like it for the air for all the reasons you like it.
i especially like that theres the separate cover for the back so the ipad is protected when you take it out of the case
and i like the way the case folds to the back and is so adjustable.
raising the ipad those few inches gives a better viewing angle on a desk, counter etc.. the best part is it's still sturdy to the point that i'm comfortable using it this way in bed.
whilst it is sturdy in that it won't fall over, it is quite wobbly when touched, so not so good for interactive use.
i have several esr products, their phone, apple watch, and airpods combo charger is about the best of the breed.
had zugu had a case available i would have immediately ordered it as ive had almost every one of their previous cases and consider them the best of the best.
the esr just doesnt feel that good in hand.
thats a good point about the sharpish edges.
i would also like the main case to have rounded edges so its more comfortable to hold.
quality is great and sure it can be a bit heavy carrying it around but having the option to detach the case eliminates that problem right away.
i wouldnt want a heavier more complicated version that just duplicates what esr has done.
it's a great, well built case.
now, i'm going from a 11 m1 pro to the air 13, but even when you don't have the tablet in the case, the case is probably the heaviest i've ever seen without a keyboard.
zugu cases do not feature detachable elements which contributes to how light they are compared to the others.
but the one i have is quite light, i dont know a specific weight but compared to any other case that is also a stand it is very light.
had it been significantly lighter, and more comfortable when carrying it in your hand, it has very sharp edges, i would have kept it.
i like everything but the weight, so i leaning toward keeping it, but we will see how after a couple weeks.
it will also allow portrait mode on the case, which i prefer for magazines and books.
i like the feature that raises it up, too.
it isnt like i am holding in hand when in use would pull from the standing case for that, but it is something i would feel in a backpack.
the zugu case wont be shipped until the end of july probably wouldnt receive it until august, so thats a long time to wait for a case.
the zugu case wont be shipped until the end of july probably wouldnt receive it until august, so thats a long time to wait for a case.
but thats really just a quibble as, if youre regularly using it, youll forget about the weight.
im not knocking esr as i use several of their other products which are outstanding but this one just didnt quite win me over.
but i would not often take the combo out and about with me, i would put the ipp in another, zugu, case or, if the esr hadnt felt like carrying a dumbbell, it would have been that one.
i would definitely appreciate something lighter, but i need a case before august, so i suspect i will stick with it despite that issue.
using it naked is not my thing.
i dont like how it feels in hand, i don't like the lack of protection, and i don't want to have to shuffle it in and out of another case.
, apart from zugu, thats the best available without a keyboard even if heavy.
i weighed this with the case and ipad and it comes to 1336g used a small kitchen scale, so probably not the exact number.
the upside is that the build keeps it steadier on uneven surfaces, like my lap.
the rebound hybrid is still rather chunky compared to the apple smart folio, but the case provides full body protection which makes it a good option for use outside of the home.
screen on the m4 is fab and it's definitely zippier but i'm undecided whether it's a keeper or not yet.
upgrading because i've enjoyed using my 12.9 over the years and got a tonne of use out of it.

i've been a bit frustrated with the export time when video editing and the time it takes to upload those videos to the cloud on my 12.9, hence wanting to upgrade for those of who who've upgraded and had the new m4 for a while what do you think?
do you find now that it' lighter, it easier to carry around and you do that more?
asking because it feels lighter and more portable than the 2018 ipp.
i really enjoy the m4 13 because of the great display and i do think i use it more because it is lighter thinner real easy to take it off the mkb and use around the house in my hands.
as for downsizing, i like the larger display and will never go back to the smaller ipad other than the mini 6 i have for out and about.
i upgraded from an 11 2018 ipad pro to the 11 m4 model.
i still largely use it for the same stuff, just everything seems to load and run a little faster and smoother.
there are some features i liked that i couldn't get previously, like the ability to instantly scan a photo or screenshot for text on the spot previously, i had to save it to my photo roll first.

at the end of the day, i probably could have stuck with my previous 2018 ipad, but given its irregular upgrade schedule, this seemed like a good time to get a new device which can support the next couple of years of software updates i am not expecting the a12x ipad pro to get ios 19.
i do love the big screen, and especially now that its oled great feedback, and valid points i agree and really those noticeable improvements.

i read elsewhere on this forum that somebody said, previous ipad wasnt slow and was responsive but when they upgraded they realised how much more responsive and what a great experience using the m4 was.
so whether it's worth it or not is entirely subjective and depends on how much spare money you have.
in any case, it's a very good model year to upgrade.
it doesn't feel much lighter the ipads with the mini led screens were heavier than the 2018 ipp.
hopefully the ipad air eventually gets promotion and i can buy that, because otherwise i won't be buying another ipad if the oleds have awful pwm flicker.
the 2018 was lighter than the m1 but the m4 is even lighter.

the nice surprises i got with the m4 the weight reduction was expected were the speakers, fuller and louder than the 2018 at max volume, and as good as the m1, despite the much thinner body, and the 80 charge threashold i leave the m4 always plugged in and this way it's always charge

i ended up keeping the m4 13inch and agree with you love that its lighter and feels more mobile and im happy to take it out of the folio and use naked on the couch and around the house, or rest on my lap when on the couch.
speakers are great and the screen is amazing!
its smoother, more buttery and acts more like my iphone 15 pro max in terms of this.
i didnt realise about the volume buttons until you said it thought it was just me my 2018 wasnt bad, but the last couple of updates especially ios 18 started to slow down the device.
i have the 2020 ipp and ended up buying the m4 ipp because apple does a damn good job at marketting and hype.
while the upgrades and the nano textured screen were awesome, the display, speakers, lightweight and new magic keyboard, i realistically did not get a different experience than my 2020 ipp.
however for a deal like you got, it may be worth it.
i personally would love the m4 ipp to be my main device, but it really has to be able to do more than a macbook air for its cost.
the build in apps like photos and contacts does have more features than the ipados version.
if youre happy with the new device and not looking back at the cost, then definitely worth it.
i will definitely be getting a new ipad in the future, but at a more reasonable price when available.

travelers could invest in the ipad pro and all its accessoriesat a price comparable to a macbook air, by the wayand know that theyre getting the best of apples tablet experience and its traditional computer experience.
the soft pleather exterior feels good in the hand and provides a secure grip, unlike some slippery plastic alternatives.
underneath the exterior is a robust combination of tpu and polycarbonate, offering what feels like very decent drop protection.
i haven't had a mishap yet, but it certainly instills confidence.
its versatile stand options, secure magnetic mounting, and thoughtful design features like air vents and apple pencil integration set it apart from many competitors.

after using it for years i can finally say one of the most worse uncomfortable cases i used , after going back to more basic light weight like the andar leather case i can use my ipad a lot better and its actually comfortable to write on even with your hand and arm laying flat on the screen unlike this case where it has a ridge that just annoys when writing on looks like you are showing the case magnetically sticking to the stainless steel refrigerator door.
i'm sure many children would like to know because their mommies can't stick the child's precious art project on their modern stainless steel refrigerator the magnetic doesn't work on that surface.
it never spontaneously collapses like with other cases.
work great on airplane seat tray, or uneven surfaces like in bed, wherever.

as for whirlpool refrigerators they do stick i have this case for my ipad pro for first time and it is defo best case ever for me.

my m1 mac mini nice that i do not need to put in the cabin luggage like laptops my mac mini is main main computingwork device with a tv used as monitor works great, especially in this very hot environment, does not overheat and stays silent.. and stays on all day, while my thinkpad is on only when needed, my ipad pro is my video watching device around the house and a second monitor for work for both the mac and the pc and my thinkpad is my work device around the house and on the go.
a laptop is best used at a desk.
